The program comprises: (i) a program cluster concept, divided into 
three phases, through program loans, to support implementation of 
the  Government’s  Public  Administration  Reform  (PAR)  Master

The  public  administration  system  in  Viet  Nam  is  characterized  by 
various  weaknesses.  These  include:  (i) inefficient  and  ineffective 
institutional  setups,  laws,  rules,  and  regulations  that  do  not 
adequately  support,  and  in  many  cases  hinder,  the  socioeconomic 
development  initiatives  of  the  country;  (ii) organizational  systems 
and processes that are generally cumbersome, highly bureaucratic, 
and  opaque;  (iii) a  poorly  paid  civil  service  characterized  by 
pervasive rent-seeking behavior, and constrained by inefficiencies in 
management; and (iv) a public finance system not fully equipped to 
meet  the  complex  fiscal  and  financial  challenges  of  a  fast-growing 
economy integrating into the global market. 
 
Since 1986, with the adoption of the policy of renovation or Doi Moi 
that has included an extensive reform agenda, Viet Nam has been 
in transition, moving from a centrally planned to a socialist-oriented 
market  economy.  While  tangible  progress  has  been  achieved 
through the structural and economic reforms, the country continues 
to face many of the major socioeconomic problems and challenges 
of an economy in transition.

II. 

THE MACROECONOMIC CONTEXT 

Reforms Followed by Rapid Progress 

 
A. 
 
2. 
With the adoption of the policy of renovation, Doi Moi, since 1986 Viet Nam has been in 
transition from a centrally planned to a socialist-oriented market economy. Viet Nam’s economy 
has  undergone  radical  changes,  achieving  almost  unparalleled  socioeconomic  success:  fast 
overall  growth,  substantial  poverty  reduction,  and  further  social  development,  including 
increased  school  attendance,  improvements  in  the  relative  status  of  women,  and  sharp 
reductions  in  illiteracy.  Gross  domestic  product  (GDP)  grew  at  an  average  annual  rate  of  8% 
during  the  1990s,  with  household  per  capita  consumption  growing  at  7.2%.  Since  1992,  Viet 
Nam  has  followed  prudent  fiscal  and  monetary  policies,  resulting  in  price  stability  and  a 
generally  stable  macroeconomy.  The  overall  consequent  development  has  been  largely 
equitable.  
 
The domestic private sector, largely made up of very small productive units, has become 
3.  
the main source of GDP with a contribution of 44%. It now accounts for nearly 25% of the labor 
force,  or  up  to  86%  if  private  agriculture  is  included.  Particularly  since  business  registration 
requirements were eased in 1999, household enterprises have proliferated and the number of 
formal private enterprises has nearly doubled. However, the potential for the development of the 
private sector remains to be more fully realized, as it is concentrated in a few industries. Some 
of  the  main  obstacles  to  private  sector  development  include  contradictory  and  unevenly 
enforced  legislation;  cumbersome  and  arbitrary  administrative  and  taxation  systems;  difficult 
access to land, credit, and business information; and inadequate physical infrastructure. State-
owned  enterprises  (SOEs)  still  dominate  industrial  production.  With  regard  to  SOEs,  while  the 
Government  recognizes  the  need  for  reforms,  only  modest  progress  has  been  achieved  in 
recent years. This also holds true for state-owned commercial banks.  
 
4. 
The  dollar  value  of  Viet  Nam’s  exports  rose  sixfold  from  1990  to  2002  and  they  have 
reoriented from the former centrally planned economies to East Asia, the European Union, and, 
increasingly, North America. Export growth has been led by light manufacturing exports and by 
agriculture  as  Viet  Nam  turned  from  being  a  food  importer  into  a  leading  exporter  of  several 
major agricultural products, with attendant benefits to the employment and incomes of the poor. 
An  early  surge  of  petroleum  exports  also  contributed  to  easing  foreign  exchange  and  budget

5. 
The early years of Doi Moi benefited from the general dynamism of the East Asia region. 
Private capital inflows into Viet Nam rose sharply in the early 1990s but declined during the mid-

B.  
 
6. 
The nature and urgency of the challenges, which Viet Nam now faces, are illustrated by 
recent  developments.  GDP  growth  was  down  to  5.8%  in  2001,  and  is  estimated  at  5.7%  for 
2002 and 6.2% for 2003. While these growth rates are among the highest worldwide, they fall 
well short of what is needed to achieve the goal of doubling GDP between 2001 and 2010.1 The 
recent slowdown in growth is all the more worrying as the weighted dollar price of agricultural 
exports fell by more than 20% in 2001, with rice, coffee, pepper, rubber, cashew-nuts, tea, and 
groundnuts  all  contributing  to  this.2  The  impact  is  all  the  stronger  as  the  terms  of  trade  have 
moved strongly against Viet Nam. The price of Viet Nam’s coffee exports has declined by more 
than 60% in the past 3 years. This phenomenon does not only affect the balance of payments 
and fiscal receipts, it also directly bears on the incomes of rural households for which there are 
few immediate alternatives, particularly in the uplands and highlands, where Viet Nam’s ethnic 
minorities and many of its poorest people are concentrated. 
 
7. 
The  constraints  on  agricultural  export  growth,  and  the  low  wages  on  which  many  light 
industry exports are predicated, point to the need to deepen and diversify Viet Nam's economic 
development. This is one of the objectives of the Government, which wants to move Viet Nam to 
at  least  middle-income  status  by  2025.  To  continue  to  achieve  sustainable,  robust  rates  of 
economic  growth,  Viet  Nam,  like  other  countries  in  the  region  before  it,  must  enable  all 
economic agents to contribute to development by engaging in the activities most in keeping with 
its  comparative  advantage.  In  particular,  the  further  development  of  the  multisector  economy 
and  the  growth  of  enterprises  outside  of  the  public  sector  need  to  be  encouraged.  However, 
their success and their attractiveness to needed foreign investment remain critically dependent 
on the Government establishing a more favorable legal and administrative environment.  
 
8.  
Viet  Nam’s  leaders,  after  intensive  debate  over  economic  strategy  and  its  implications, 
have  decided  that  adaptation  and  continued  fast,  sustainable,  and  equitable  development

1. 

Overview 

 
10.  With  Doi  Moi,  Viet  Nam’s  public  administration  has  undergone  some  major  changes, 
albeit not as far-reaching as that of its economy. Reforms carried out since the late 1980s have 
substantially reduced the scope of government intervention in household and personal activities, 
in circumscribing social behavior, and in economic life. The intensity and extent of the changes 
are embedded in the role that the public sector has played over the past decade in the country’s 
record of robust economic growth, social progress, and poverty reduction.  
 
Traditionally,  the  public  sector  occupied  the  bulk  of  Viet  Nam’s  social  space.  With  Doi 
11. 
Moi, its intervention in most aspects of society has fallen, even as it has built up its interventions 
in some needed areas, such as infrastructure development and poverty reduction. For instance, 
there was little need for many of the traditional activities of a customs administration when the 
state  alone  traded;  immigration  officers  when  there  was  little  foreign  travel;  or  even  for  traffic 
rules when there were few mechanized vehicles. In recent years, however, laws and regulations 
have been changed, and efforts made to adapt policies and service delivery mechanisms with 
the changing role of the state. Financial management has been tightened, halting the taxation of 
society  through  inflation  that  had  characterized  the  previous  decade,  and  preventing  its 
recurrence. The Government now emphasizes the need for the public administration to reduce 
its traditional extensive and intrusive, hands-on interventions and to move to the formulation and 
implementation  of  policies  to  indirectly  influence  private  behavior.  An  overriding  goal  of  the 
Government’s PAR MP3 is to reorient the role of the state, "from rowing to steering”, as the PAR 
MP itself puts it, as Viet Nam progresses in its transition to a socialist-oriented market economy.

reorientation and renovation of the systems and machinery of government remain at best only

The Government and the Communist Party of Viet Nam (CPV) have given strong signals 
in  recent  years  that  they  intend  to  reform  the  public  administration  system.  There  are  at  least 
three main reasons for the strong support to PAR by the Government and CPV. First, the SEDS 
and  CPRGS  call  for  the  doubling  of  GDP  and  reduction  of  national  standard-base  poverty

other challenges, Viet Nam is currently not on track to meet the growth target, with average and

needed, including the far-reaching reforms called for under the PAR MP. A second reason for 
the  strong  support  for  PAR  is  that  Viet  Nam  has  commitments  under  the  bilateral  trade 
agreement with the United States, and would have new ones as part of WTO accession. A more 
efficient and effective ethical bureaucracy is essential to meet these commitments, and in turn to 
promote  business  investment  and  economic  growth.  The  third,  and  perhaps  a  more  important 
reason,  is  that  Viet  Nam's  leaders  are  trying  to  maintain  the  high  level  of  respect  they  have

corrupt  and  incompetent  local  officials  to  the  attention  of  higher  authorities  and  that  this  will

102.   The program entails three types of risks: some of the necessary measures may not be 
agreed;  some  may  be  agreed  but  not  carried  out;  and  some  may  be  carried  out  but  with 
unintended  impacts.  In  terms  of  the  first  type  of  risk,  intellectual  consensus,  political  will  or 
capacity, and constraints on financial and human resources do not allow every reform measure 
to  go  as  far  or  as  fast  as  some  of  their  proponents  would  wish.  Thus,  the  program  does  not 
constitute  an  ideal  set  of  reform  measures  for  the  swiftest  conceivable  transformation  of  Viet 
Nam's public administration. It constitutes a set of feasible measures on which consensus could 
be reached and for which resources can be found. It will not bring instantaneous modernization 
but if properly implemented, it will bring gradual but solid improvements. 
 
103.   The  second  type  of  risk  is  that  decisions  may  not  be  translated  into  actions  or 
implementation  may  be  delayed.  Governments  often  announce  that  they  are  going  to  do 
something (sometimes in response to measures and actions imposed by lenders), but either do 
not intend to or are unable to give practical effect to such decisions. Such inability may be due 
to political constraints on action or unwillingness to offend powerful interests. It may also be due 
to  a  failure  of  the  instruments  of  governance  or  to  instructions  being  heard  but  ineffectively 
carried  out.  Naturally,  these  two  causes  often  combine,  particularly  when  the  civil  service 
constitutes  an  effective  political  force  and  is  itself  the  object  of  reform  decisions.  These  are 
relevant  concerns  for  an  extensive  range  of  reforms  that  will  affect  all  levels  of  public 
administration in Viet Nam over a long period. However, precisely because the PAR program, 
though bold, is not overly ambitious, the second risk does not appear overwhelming.20 
 
104.  Nevertheless,  while  high-level  political  commitment  is  not  in  doubt,  a  number  of 
elements  need  to  be  addressed  to  ensure  effective  reform  implementation.  Resistance  to 
reforms needs to be managed actively (including discussion with stakeholders and the diffusion 
of  information  about  reform  objectives),  and  not  allowed  to  halt  or  derail  reforms.  Adequate 
financial  and  human  resources  are  also  essential.  Implementation  must  be  managed  in  a 
practical,  realistic,  and  sequenced  way,  paying  keen  attention  to  the  proper  linkages  between 
various  reforms.  Adjustments  will  often  be  required  in  the  light  of  experience,  hence  the 
program's accent on multiyear rolling plans, management information systems, and monitoring 
and  evaluation,  all  of  which  presume  a  strong  central  leadership  and  management. 
Organizational  arrangements  for  the  management  of  PAR  implementation  must  be  highly 
effective,  and  firm  leadership  must  be  provided  throughout  the  process.  The  strong  political 
commitment  shown  in  the  formulation  and  approval  of  the  PAR  MP  must  be  maintained 
throughout the reform implementation process, and be reflected in public advocacy and active 
participation.  One  key  related  task  will  be  building  ownership  and  accountability  in  the  line 
agencies  that  will  have  to  take  most  of  the  concrete  implementation  actions.  Without  such 
ownership it will be difficult to move reforms and restructuring forward. Given these risks, much 
of the policy matrix is tailored to ensuring that the implementation process is in fact effective and 
that these risks are accordingly minimized.

PUBLIC ADMINISTRATION SECTOR IN VIET NAM 

1. 
Viet  Nam  has  a  four-tiered  administrative  structure—central,  provincial,  district,  and 
commune  levels.  There  are  five  state  institutions  at  the  central  level,  with  counterparts  at 
subordinate  levels:  (i) the  500-member  elected  National  Assembly  and  its  elected  local 
counterparts,  the  People's  Councils;  (ii) the  President,  who  is  supported  by  a  vice  president; 
(iii) the  Government,  and  its  local  counterparts,  the  People's  Committees;  (iv) the  Supreme 
Court and the local People's Courts; and (v) the Supreme Institute of Procuracy, and the local 
People's  Procuracy.  At  the  provincial  level,  the  administrative  structure  has  a  series  of 
divisions—districts, provincial cities, and towns. Cities under direct central rule are divided into 
urban  districts,  rural  districts,  and  towns.  At  the  district  level,  rural  districts  are  divided  into 
communes,  townships,  and  wards,  while  urban  districts  are  classified  as  wards.  At  the 
commune level, communes are divided into urban and rural.

and legislative body and that it exercises "supreme oversight" over all state activities. All state 
bodies  such  as  the  Government,  the  People's  Supreme  Court,  and  the  People's  Supreme 
Institute  of  Procuracy  are  held  accountable  to,  and  are  appointed  by,  the  National  Assembly. 
Over time, the National Assembly has enhanced its legislative role and its level of oversight of 
executive government bodies.

3.  Human Resources: Improving the Quality of the Civil Service 

 

20.  The overall quality of the civil service is weak. This in turn impacts adversely on levels of 
organizational performance. Many current staff are seen as inadequately skilled or motivated to 
properly perform their duties.13 While Viet Nam seeks a civil service that is of higher quality in 
the  sense  that  it  is  competent,  professional  and  ethical,  there  is  a  need  to  develop  detailed 
profiles  of  the  professional  and  other  skills  required  by  civil  servants  to  support  policy-making 
and  service  delivery.  Much  of  the  existing  legal  and  policy  framework  for  the  operation  of  the 
civil  service  is  fragmented  and  the  various  laws  and  decrees  need  to  be  reviewed  and 
modernized so as to set out the roles, duties and conditions of service in a contemporary way. 
More  recently,  MOHA  has  been  preparing  a  submission  on  the  scope  for  decentralization  of 
personnel management. The future institutional arrangements and the powers for managing the 
civil  service  would  need  to  be  part  of  that  examination.14  While  there  have  been  a  number  of 
increases in salary paid to civil servants, most do not earn a living wage.15 This affects levels of 
motivation  in  work  and  encourages  rent-seeking  behavior.  Following  review,  proposals  for 
raising salaries through a series of increases to a minimum wage level and for fully monetizing 
salary, and for linking pay and performance, have been formulated and are to be submitted to 
the Government.16  

21.  Paradoxically, there is lack of qualified staff to meet the new requirements and to perform 
accordingly  whereas  at  the  same  time  there  are  many  who  are  unable  to  meet  the  current 
performance  requirements.  The  Government  launched  a  rightsizing  program  in  200017  with  a 
target of a 15% reduction in payroll. The program is ongoing with about 3% of civil servants18 so 
far affected. Staff who are made redundant are compensated. Two key concerns are to ensure 
that the most inefficient civil servants are made redundant and provided with compensation and, 
second,  that  the  exercise  is  linked  to  the  planned  restructuring  of  the  civil  service  toward 
ensuring that civil servants with the right skills are placed in the right job. 

22.  The  Government  has  therefore  given  more  attention  proportionately  to  improving  the 
quality of civil servants, as they will ultimately be the ones who carry out the reforms and must in

 Financial  management  reform  in  Viet  Nam  has  proceeded  slowly  and  until  relatively

Supporting the Public Administration Reform (PAR) Master Program offers an important opportunity for improving 
government  efficiency  and  effectiveness;  strengthening  accountability,  transparency,  and  good  governance;  and 
promoting  participation  and  democracy.  All  of  these  are  valuable  contributors  to  achieving  poverty  reduction, 
growth, and social development. There is a strong link between effective administrations at all levels and poverty 
reduction. The Comprehensive Poverty Reduction and Growth Strategy (CPRGS) calls for accelerating the reform 
of institutions and polices that affect poor people.  This loan and attached technical assistance (TA) will aim, inter 
alia, at ensuring that the PAR will be implemented in a pro-poor manner.   

Poverty Analysis 

     Proposed Classification: Other  (governance) 

PAR measures will have significant positive impact upon poverty reduction.  

As the result of economic growth by efficient and effective PAR, more opportunities will be created for the poor to 
engage in trading and improve home-based enterprises. 

Strong  indirect  benefits  are  expected  to  reach  the  poor  in  terms  of  improved  service  delivery  and  promoting 
participation and democracy. Any efficiency gain in service delivery will directly benefit the poor. The poor's access 
to  basic  services  and  infrastructure,  especially  in  the  mountainous  regions  and  in  poor  urban  areas,  must  be 
ensured as a priority.  

Careful consideration should be given to provision of services through the private sector to enhance public service 
provision to fill the gaps. While private sector involvement in providing services could help expand the number of 
jobs and in the process create new employment opportunities, prices of services will likely go up. To minimize such 
impacts, services at the community level need to be provided at increased cost efficiency. 

Decentralized  public  administration  should  make  local  level  government  be  accountable  to  the  poor  for  their 
participation in decision-making on development programs and delivery of services.
